title: Congo - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

On 12 January 2021, a group of men attacked 1 police station in Nkayi town (Nkayi, Bouenza) in reaction to the death of a man allegedly killed by the police. The police intervened and dispersed the mob. [size=no report]

On 31 December 2020, a group of youths demonstrated in Brazzaville (Brazzaville, Brazzaville) against the curfew imposed during the Christmas holidays by the government. They chanted songs against the curfew and other restrictions established to control the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 31 December 2020, a group of youths demonstrated in Pointe-Noire (Pointe-Noire, Pointe-Noire) against the curfew imposed during the Christmas holidays by the government. They chanted songs against the curfew and other restrictions established to control the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
RDD: Rally for Democracy and Development

On 25 December 2020, a member of the opposition for the RDD party and his family were beaten and extorted by the police at a checkpoint in Brazzaville city (Brazzaville, Brazzaville). The checkpoint was erected to control the curfew imposed due to the coronavirus pandemic.

On 7 December 2020, a group of teachers (volunteer category) demonstrated in front of the Treasury department building in Brazzaville city (Brazzaville, Brazzaville) to demand their unpaid allowances of the last 6 months. [size=no report]
On 21 October 2020, a group of local people killed 1 man in Brazzaville (Brazzaville, Brazzaville). He was accused of being a thief. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2020, a group of local people demonstrated in Nkayi city (Nkayi, Bouenza) to show their refusal to wear face mask. They burned face masks in front of the police in reaction to the killing of a woman by a policeman early that week following a dispute because she had refused to wear a face mask. Wearing face mask was declared mandatory due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, a group of assistant teachers (called voluntary teachers) demonstrated in Brazzaville (Brazzaville, Brazzaville) to show their outrage and claim their unpaid salaries of the last 8 months. [size=no report]
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

On 29 September 2020, a group of local people vandalized several public buildings including a police station and a public market in Nkayi city (Nkayi, Bouenza). They looted and torched these buildings in reaction to the killing of a woman by a policeman after she had refused to wear a face mask. The state forces, outnumbered, fled the village. Wearing face mask was declared mandatory due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
On 17 September 2020, a group of teachers marched in Brazzaville (Brazzaville, Brazzaville) to demand their unpaid salaries of the last 6 months. [size=no report]
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

On 19 August 2020, a group of local residents barricaded the road with burning tires in Brazzaville for the second straight day to resist an eviction operation by the local authorities. The police intervened and disperse the group using teargas. [size=no report]
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

On 18 August 2020, a group of local residents barricaded the road with burning tires in Brazzaville city, to resist an eviction operation by the local authorities. The police intervened and disperse the group using teargas. [size=no report]
On 8 March 2020, women and men demonstrated in commemoration of International Women's day near Hinda (Kouilou). [size=no report]
On 11 February 2020, Gabonese gendarmes tortured civilians and looted their houses near Moungoundou-Nord and Pana border villages (Moutamba, Niari).

As reported on 10 February 2020, 1200 former workers of La Poste staged an ongoing protest in Brazzaville requesting for the payment of their retirement that they would not have received in the last 11 years. [size=1200]
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

On 25 December 2019, a civilian and a policeman were killed during an arrest in Odziba, south of Congo. Two other people were injured. The policeman was then killed by the population who was very angry and who also burnt the police office.

On 11 October, in Kimongo, unspecified number of residents blocked the main road with barricades in protest of poor condition of the road that led to frequent accidents. Barricades were removable and no violence occurred. [size=no report]
On 9 September, in Brazzaville, around 500 judges protested in front of Ministry of Justice, demanding unlock of the urgent budget for public service. [size=500]
On 27 August, in Brazzaville, unspecified number of people protested against expropriation of their property in favour of the Kintele International Conference Centre. [size=no report]
On 6 August, in Brazzaville, an unspecified number of people protested against unemployment. [size=no report]
On 6 August, in Louvakou area [coded to Dolisie], several dozen of youth protested against unemployment. [size=several dozen]
On 23 July, in Brazzaville, unspecified number of people protested in front of ministry of finance, demanding payment of overdue bills for the land expropriation. [size=no report]
On 17 July, in Brazzaville, unspecified number of workers of the Congo Post and Savings Company protested against non-payment of salaries. [size=no report]
Labour Group (Republic of Congo); Journalists (Republic of Congo)
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
On 16 July, in Brazzaville, police intervened during a protest of STPU (Public Transport Company) workers. Police forced journalists to erase the images and footage. [size=no report]
Women (Democratic Republic of Congo); Farmers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
In July 2019, military forces of Angola reportedly raped an unspecified number of DRC women working in the fields in Kimongo (Niari) in Republic of Congo.

On 1 July, in Brazzaville, unspecified number of students protested against lack of employment opportunities in public service after graduation by organizing a sit-in in front of Ministry of Public Service. [size=no report]
Former Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
On 5 June, 50 soldiers have protested for better treatment of wounded soldiers. [size=50]
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
17 April 2019 (on or before). Students at Marien Ngouabi University demonstrated, calling for scholarship arrear payments. Police intervened and dispersed the demonstrators. [size=no report]

28 - 30 March 2019. Amid rising tensions between Angola and the Republic of Congo, Angolan military forces reportedly crossed the border into the forest areas near the Illou-Panga villages, in the Kimongo district. The deployment of Angolan forces at the border and into Congolese territory caused some of the local population to flee the area.
Former Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
25 March 2019. Former auxiliary police officers protested in Brazzaville, demanding jobs. The demonstrators were arrested. [size= approximately 20]
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-); Taxi Drivers (Republic of Congo)
07 March. A group of men armed with knives broke the windshields of taxis, which belonged to the local police chief in Dolisie. An investigation was launched.
Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
08 February. Citizens of the DRC residing in Brazzaville besieged the DRC embassy claiming they were owed payments from the ambassador.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
06 February. A police officer assaulted a three year-old child, beating him against a tree in the Bacougni neighborhood of Dolisie. Locals and other police officers intervened.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-) Gendarmerie

22 December. Following the death of a college student in Gendarmerie custody, students ransacked university offices before marching to the Gendarmerie with the body of the deceased. The demonstrators barricaded roads and burned tires. The Gendarmerie dispersed the demonstrators by with tear gas and by firing into the air. Two people were wounded by gun shots.
Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Weapons seizure: on August 29, the Republic of Congo Government launched a national operation aimed at collecting weapons used during the civil war of 2016 by the Ninja Militia. A few days after the operation started, hundreds of weapons had already been collected in the district of Vindza and nearly 2,000 nationwide, out of the expected three thousand.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); RFI

On the night of 22 to 23 July, in Brazzaville, 13 people died inside the Chacona police station in Mpila. The Congolese Observatory of Human Rights claims to have collected several testimonies claiming that they died at the police station after police violence. Other reports suggest they died after clashes involving the 'black babies' armed group.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

In the night between 22-23 July, sixteen people were arrested after the death of a man in their neighbourhood in Brazzaville and 13 of them were tortured to death. The government admitted the police responsibility soon after.
On 4 May, the body of the Senegalese Ambassador to Republic of Congo was found dead in Diata Park in Brazzaville. He was allegedly murdered.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
A student union leader was tortured in a police station in Congo. He was beaten with sticks and had plastic burned on his back. No exact date provided (dated to source).
On 18 March, an elderly man accused of witchcraft was burned alive in front of a crowd in Banda, Niari.

Looting: On the night of 8-9 March, the HQ of the Meeting for Peace and Human Rights (RPDH) in Pointe-Noire were broken into by an unidentified group who took equipment selectively, indicating a political motive.
Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Agreement: on 7 March, the Ministry of Interior released four prisoners of the Ninja militia close to Pastor Ntumi as part of the peace agreement and cease-fire in December 2017.
On 3 March, a march was held by the Congolese Wildlife and Protected Areas Agency (ACFAP) in Brazzaville to oppose poachers and raise awareness of challenges for wildlife.
On 18 February, students at a high school in Dolisie destroyed billboards to express anger against a colleague's death.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-) Prison Guards
On 16 February, a journalist was abducted from a Brazzaville clinic where he was hospitalised. He was reported to have been taken by the director of the Brazzaville prison.
Movement of forces: the Angolan army have reportedly been conducting regular operations in Kimongo in Niari and surrounding areas (including Ilou-Panga)
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
On 18 January, students clashed with police officers who used tear gas after the funeral of a student from their college in Dolisie. Several students were arrested.
On 10 January, angry workers at the Foralac Forest Company in Makabana burned tires around the factory and took two tank carriers hostage to demand wages.
On 4 January, a group labelled the 'black babies' (Bebes Noir) attack Mfilou in the 7th district of Brazzaville injuring a number of people.
Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
Agreement: signed on 23/12 between the Congolese Government and the Ninja Militia group.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Lawyers in Congo Brazzaville gathered at the Poointe Noire Bar in solidarity with a colleague who had been arrested earlier in the week. The police broke up the meeting.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Journalists in Brazzaville came to meet with the lawyers of a prisoner, but were arrested and beaten by security forces wearing civilian clothes at the HQ of The African Week. Shots and injuries were sustained.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Supporters of Claudine Munari held a peaceful demonstration at the Moungali roundabout in Brazzaville, demanding the liberation of political prisoners. They were dispersed by the police using teargas.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Students at high schools in Brazzaville have been rioting and causing violence. The police responded strongly.
Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Agreement: The Congolese Government has offered an amnesty to rebel groups operating in the Pool region.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
TOTAL workers demonstrated against the economic treatement: the demonstration was broken up with teargas.
The citizen movement, Ras-le-Bol held a peaceful demonstration outside the University Hospital in Brazzaville, following a report detailing abuses and dysfunctions in the hospital.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
There was a demonstration in Brazzaville to call for a end to the violence in Pool and for the release of political prisoners. The police dispersed the protesters and arrested 10 people.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

People held a sit-in outside Colonel Tsenzele's residence, near the Mpila barracks, to protest the killing of a local youth. The police used baton sticks to disperse the protesters. No reported injury.
Ninja Nsiloulous attacked buses travelling from Brazzaville to Pointe Noire. Women on the buses were raped and 3 passengers were killed, including an off-duty policemen.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

An army position in the Pool region was attacked by Ninjas-Nsiloulous militiamen in the Herilla area of Mayama locality, causing a number of injuries and deaths among the soldiers (unknown fatalities).
On 5 April, villagers in Ogooue in Zanaga district in Lekoumou demonstrated for the departure of the sub-prefect. Reports of property destruction by youth who broke a bridge.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Republic of Congo police forces claim to have dislodged alleged Ninjas Nisloulou rebels from Mpi village in Pool. The rebels left behind supplies, weapons and dependents. No injuries reported.
A protest was held outside the HQ of Equatorial Congo Airlines in Brazzaville over the alleged mismanagement of the state airline.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
A Republic of Congo police spokesman claimed that at least 15 suspected Ninjas Nsiloulou militants have been killed in a recent operation by Congolese security forces in the Pool region.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
IDC: Initiative For Democracy in Congo
Arrests: A former presidential candidate and president of the IDC party, Andre Okombi Salissa, was arrested in Brazzaville for 'endangering the internal security of the state'.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-) Prison Guards
3 people, including a police officer, were killed and 4 injured in a shooting at a prison in Brazzaville. The incident was described variously as a prison riot and/or an escape attempt.
A transport vehicle traveling from Brazzaville to Kindamba was torched by suspected Ninjas militiamen. At least one passenger was assaulted by the militiamen before the vehicle was burned.

About 300 people have marched in the Republic of Congos capital to demand that the country leave the International Criminal Court. Thursdays march comes shortly after three African countries, South Africa, Gambia and Burundi, announced they would leave the tribunal.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Suspected Ninjas militiamen clashed with police on the Mindouli-Kinkala axis, injuring one person seriously.
Property destruction: Suspected Ninjas militiamen ambushed a convoy of vehicles in the Ngandou area, between Mindouli and Mayama. 3 vehicles were burned, although no casualties were reported.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Hundreds of people have fled alleged attacks against civilians and military targets in the Kinkala area of Pool by Ninjas militiamen. No casualties were reported.
Hundreds of people have fled alleged attacks against civilians and military targets in the Kinkala area of Pool by Ninjas militiamen. No casualties were reported.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Xinhua

At least 14 people were killed, primarily military, police, gendarmerie personnel but also including a driver, in an attack by suspected Ninjas militiamen on a freight train near the Mindouli train station. The train was bound for Kinkembo.
IDC: Initiative For Democracy in Congo

Congolese opposition figure Augustin Kala Kala, a close associate of the IDCs most recent presidential candidate, was kidnapped. He was later released on Oct.13 with serious injuries. It was not clear who the culprits were.
Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Xinhua
Nsiloulou Ninjas militiamen attacked an a bus in Kinkala district, causing 3 injuries and destroying the vehicle.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
2 soldiers were killed in a clash with Ninjas militiamen in the Mangola area of Pool as they were guarding a Chinese road construction site.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
AFP; Xinhua; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)

After Nsiloulou Ninjas attacked a bus in the Kinkala area, they attacked an ambulance which came to take away the victims of the first attack and destroyed the vehicle. The driver, another civilian and 2 Congolese soldier were killed in the attack, while 4 others were injured, one seriously.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

23 people have been killed by Ninjas militiamen in the Pool area according to the Congolese Minister for Justice and Human Rights. Those killed include 6 soldiers, 4 police, 2 gendarmes, and 11 civilians (20 coded in other events).
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
2 police officers were killed by suspected Nsiloulou Ninjas militiamen in Mindouli.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Movement of forces: Opposition forces claimed that military and police forces have been deployed in the Pool region near Mayama, the home of an opposition leader. This follows activities in the area considered a support base for the opposition after violence following President Sassous re-election.
OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
Ten political parties, including the PR, DDC, CAR and others have created in Brazzaville a new opposition coalition named the Rally for the Congolese Opposition (OCR).

Nsiloulou Ninjas militiamen have allegedly carried out a large number of crimes in the Pool area since their attack on the capital in March, including rapes, thefts, robberies, killings (unknown fatalities).
Property destruction: Suspected Ninjas militia members burned some trucks in the Pool region.

After a train service between Brazzaville and Pointe-Norie was cancelled, angry travelers demonstrated in front of the station to demand either information or their money back. Police were present during the incident.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Agreement: One of the main leaders of the former Ninja militia, Augustin Bassoumba, has surrendered to Congolese authorities along with his family.

After a group of knife-wielding assailants attacked a man, residents of the Nzoko area of Brazzaville came to his aid and fought off the assailants. The brawl was dispersed by police who fired tear gas.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Gunfire and shelling allegedly took place in the Pool region in which military forces have been operating recently allegedly against Ninjas militia, although few details were given in the report.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

A group of police and military police clashed in the Talangai area of Brazzaville after the military police unit attempted to arrest a police officer for 'improper conduct on a motorcycle'. The police officer called on his colleagues and the dispute resulted in a gunfight. Some injuries were reported.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Non-violent activity: A large police presence has been reported outside the homes of three main opposition leaders (and failed presidential candidates) following expected protests against President Sassous re-election. The protest was cancelled due to this action.

Property destruction: 9 vehicles, including taxis and trucks, were set on fire by alleged Ninja militiamen between Mayama and Kindamba. The owners were reported to have been forced to leave their vehicles while being threatened with guns.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
'Intense shelling' has again been reported in Soumouna (near Kinkale) as well as 'other areas' in the Pool region. No specific casualties were reported, and it was not clear what was being targeted.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Military helicopters were reported to have again attacked several localities in Pool region which are seen as loyal to former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi. Soumouna, near Kinkale, Mayama and Vindza have been hit, some more than once, in recent days. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Military helicopters were reported to have again attacked several localities in Pool region which are seen as loyal to former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi. Soumouna, near Kinkale, Mayama and Vindza have been hit, some more than once, in recent days. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Military helicopters were reported to have again attacked several localities in Pool region which are seen as loyal to former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi. Soumouna, near Kinkale, Mayama and Vindza have been hit, some more than once, in recent days. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Teachers (Republic of Congo); Students (Republic of Congo)

Vindza, a previous area of residence for former leader of the Ninjas militia Pastor Ntoumi, was allegedly struck by military helicopters. A resident claimed he saw '40 shells fall early in the morning mainly on schools and houses' with the residents fleeing the area. No casualties were reported. Vindza was attacked on either Apr.6 or 7.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Soumouna, near Kinkale, and Mayama were reportedly struck by helicopters again on Apr.6. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.
Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Security Measures: President Sassou dismissed former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi (Fredereic Ntoumi Bintsamou) from his post as General Delegate to the President of the Republic, following an alleged Ninja attack on Brazzaville and military assaults on areas believed to be loyal to Pastor Ntoumi in Pool region.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Soumouna, near Kinkale, and Mayama were reportedly struck by helicopters again on Apr.6. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Military helicopters allegedly bombed Soumouna village, near Kinkale, including the HQ of former Ninjas Nsiloulou leader Pastor Ntoumi, with no reports of casualties, after violence in Brazzaville on Apr.4. A second attack was reported the next day. The BBC also reported that further attacks had been carried out against Ntoumis village in the area, killing the whole population based on a Facebook post, but this could not be confirmed.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Military helicopters allegedly fired on buildings in the Mayama area that former rebel leader Pastor Ntoumi had established. Clashes were also reported between the Ninjas militia and the military.
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Military helicopters allegedly bombed Soumouna village, near Kinkale, including the HQ of former Ninjas Nsiloulou leader Pastor Ntoumi, with no reports of casualties, after violence in Brazzaville on Apr.4. A second attack was reported the next day. The BBC also reported that further attacks had been carried out against Ntoumis village in the area, killing the whole population based on a Facebook post, but this could not be confirmed.
MCDDI: Congolese Movement for Democracy and Integral Development

President Sassou was re-elected during the Republic of Congos 2016 presidential election. The election occurred on Mar.20, and Sassou was confirmed as the winner on Mar.24. The constitutional court of RoC validated the results on Apr.4, confirmining President Sassous re-election. The results resulted in protests and are believed to have motivated attacks by Ninja militias on Apr.4. Upon hearing the poll, opposition supporters erected roadblocks in Makelekele
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
AP; Xinhua; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Deutsche Welle; AFP

Ninja Nsiloulou militiamen allegedly infiltrated Brazzaville and attacked a military position in Mayanga and the central police station of Djoue, as well as the police stations of the Bacongo, Makelekele, Lemina and Kinsoudi neighbourhoods, all in the southern areas said to be loyal to the opposition. These police stations were burned, along with many buildings in the Makelekele area, including the mayors office. Gun battles between the militiamen and police/military involving heavy and automatic weapons were reported. There were implications that the attacks were related to the recent presidential election, but no proof was provided. The government also accused the militiamen of committing 'various atrocities on civilians'. In total, 17 people, including 3 police, 2 civilians and 12 militiamen, were killed in the fighting, while 6 police were injured. At least 55 alleged Ninja militiamen were arrested.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

A dozen journalists were beaten at the Maya-Maya airport in Brazzaville by the police. They were awaiting the arrival of General Mokoko who has recently announced his candidacy for the early presidential vote in March.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
FROCAD: Front for the Constitutional Order and Democratic Change; UDC: Union for Congolese Democracy

Arrests: At least 100 young people were arrested between Dec.18-21 by Congolese police, allegedly to intimidate protesters ahead of elections, although the police have said the raids were to ensure security during new years celebration. The people targeted included UDC and Frocad activists.

Students from the ENS and NPHS schools prevented the holding of courses to protest the killing of a Congolese student by a foreign student earlier in the week. The demonstrators vandalized buildings and attempted to burn the Faculty of Letters.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

2 men set fire to a market in the Ouenze district of Brazzaville, but it was stopped and they were arrested before it could spread. They were allegedly paid to do so, and it is believed there may have been a political motive.
FROCAD: Front for the Constitutional Order and Democratic Change
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
AFP; Radio Okapi; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)

Clashes were reported between police and youths in the southwest district of Brazzaville. The youths erected barricades and burned tires to block traffic. 18 'members of the opposition' were also arrested, with police alleging that they caught them trying to make molotov cocktails. Among the 18 were 6 leaders of the Congolese opposition, including of FROCAD.

Demonstrators supporting the 'yes' side of the constitutional referendum to allow President Sassou to have another term staged a peaceful protests in another part of Brazzaville while opposition activists clashed with police.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); RFI

4 people were killed in violent clashes in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire between security forces, who fired tear gas and shot into the air, and demonstrators who were protesting against the holding of a constitutional referendum to allow President Sassou to run again. 3 of those killed were in Brazzaville, at least 2 of whom died by gunshot, while 10 people were also injured, including 5 by gunfire. 3 police were also seriously injured. 16 people were arrested and there were reports of houses being burned, including that of the Minister of Trade and Supply. A police station was also allegedly burnt down.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
AFP; RFI; AP; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)

4 people were killed in violent clashes in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire between security forces, who fired tear gas and shot into the air, and demonstrators who were protesting against the holding of a constitutional referendum to allow President Sassou to run again. 3 of those killed were in Brazzaville, at least 2 of whom died by gunshot, while 10 people were also injured, including 5 by gunfire. 3 police were also seriously injured. 16 people were arrested and there were reports of houses being burned, including that of the Minister of Trade and Supply. A police station was also allegedly burnt down.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Dozens of protesters against the constitutional referendum clashed with the police, who allegedly had to fire into the air several times to disperse them.
Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Demonstrators protesting against the constitutional referendum allegedly took the Minister of Public Works hostage for nearly 5 hours before releasing him.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

According to Reporters Without Borders, a journalist was abducted by men in uniform after being repeatedly threatened by the Pointe Noire police. After escaping he has continued to be threatened with kidnapping and death by the local authorities.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Angry youths attacked a police colonel in Pointe-Noire following violent protests the day before. They seriously injured him before security forces were able to disperse the mob and get the colonel to a hospital.

Demonstrators in the Nkouikou district burned tires and blocked traffic to express their anger after hearing that opposition leaders have been banned from traveling to Brazzaville. The ban was lifted by the afternoon.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Xinhua; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)

6 people were injured during clashes between radical elements of the opposition police during demonstrations against an extended term for President Sassou in Pointe Noire. An opposition leader stated that 13 people had been injured at a press conference the next day. There were also reports of tires being burned, shops being looted, and some violence against civilians and police elsewhere in the city.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Tens of thousands of supporters of Congolese President Sassou took to the streets in Brazzaville to support his bid to change the constitution to allow him to run for another term and to remove the age limit of 70 on the presidency. At least 6 demonstrators were arrested.
A collective of students from Marien Ngouabi University organized a peaceful march in Brazzaville against the use of violence in politics.
Town hall workers in Pointe-Noire barricaded the entrance to the municipal garage in the Mpita district to demand resolution of their grievances, including a drawdown in salaries.
FROCAD: Front for the Constitutional Order and Democratic Change; UDC: Union for Congolese Democracy

Thousands of Congolese demonstrated in Brazzaville to oppose the constitutional referendum announced by President Sassou to allow him to run for another term. It was allegedly the largest events held by the opposition since Sassou came to power in 1997. The event was orgnaized by FROCAD and the Union for Congolese Democracy (UDC).
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Land owners held a sit in to demand payment for land seized to build an olympic village three years ago. Police dispersed the protesters using tear gas.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

Weapons Seizure: Police seized explosive materials on the outskirts of Brazzaville which they believe were to be used for 'militant acts' in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire. They were taken from the home of a gang leader who had networks in both cities.
Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
Movement of forces: 140 members of the 'Formed Police Unit (UPC)' left Brazzaville to join MINUSCA for deployment around Bangui and its surroundings.

Thousands of 2015 Baccalaureate candidates rioted in the streets and at various examinations centres in Brazzaville (particularly Ouenze and Bakongo districts) and set up barricades and burned tires, with similar events reported in Pointe-Noire and Dolisie, following the announcement that the general BA tests would be cancelled due to large-scale fraud that has bee found. The student protesters attacked vehicles and buildings, broke windows, and blocked traffic.

Thousands of 2015 Baccalaureate candidates rioted in the streets and at various examinations centres in Brazzaville (particularly Ouenze and Bakongo districts) and set up barricades and burned tires, with similar events reported in Pointe-Noire and Dolisie, following the announcement that the general BA tests would be cancelled due to large-scale fraud that has bee found. The student protesters attacked vehicles and buildings, broke windows, and blocked traffic.

Thousands of 2015 Baccalaureate candidates rioted in the streets and at various examinations centres in Brazzaville (particularly Ouenze and Bakongo districts) and set up barricades and burned tires, with similar events reported in Pointe-Noire and Dolisie, following the announcement that the general BA tests would be cancelled due to large-scale fraud that has bee found. The student protesters attacked vehicles and buildings, broke windows, and blocked traffic.
A political 'mega rally' was held by the Dynamic for the New Republic (DNR) political movement involving youths, women and many different segments of society to suppot a national dialogue.
